column9: R.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|1||339|Electron microprobe analyses have been performed on glasses of impact origin in Apollo 11 breccias (10059
column16: 15427). These glasses were produced by shock melting of regolith
column17: rather than of rock. Simple concepts for better understanding and interpreting the chemical data from impact glasses have been developed. These concepts are a significant improvement on earlier strategies
column18: which centered principally on cluster analysis. Using ratios of refractory lithophile elements
column19: the compositional effects of fractional vaporization often associated with impact melting to obtain chemical information about the mare and highland components in the regoliths parental to the glasses have been 'seen through'. This method is also applied to the mare-derived impact glasses from Apollo 16 in order to place constraints on the types of volcanic components occurring in Mare Nectaris. Since impact glasses can be used to derive chemical constraints on the indigenous lithologies comprising multi-component regoliths; the frequent occurrence of these glasses
column20: as well as their low masses
column21: should make them critically important for study when small quantities of grab-samples are returned by future unmanned spacecraft from planets
column23: and asteroids where regoliths are present.|
